title: Josh Labandeira
text:
John Joshua Labandeira (born February 25, 1979 in <a href="Tulare%2C%20California">Tulare, California</a>) is a former <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> player. He played <a href="second%20base">second base</a>/<a href="shortstop">shortstop</a> and batted and threw <a href="right-handed">right-handed</a>.
Career.
Labandeira attended <a href="Monache%20High%20School">Monache High School</a> in <a href="Porterville%2C%20California">Porterville, California</a> and chose <a href="Fresno%20State%20University">Fresno State University</a> as the college he wished to attend. While at Fresno, he lettered in four different sports: <a href="wrestling">wrestling</a>, <a href="soccer">soccer</a>, <a href="American%20football">football</a> and <a href="baseball">baseball</a>. Labandeira majored in <a href="kinesiology">kinesiology</a>. As a sophomore, he attended <a href="College%20of%20the%20Sequoias">College of the Sequoias</a> in <a href="Visalia%2C%20California">Visalia</a> (<a href="Bob%20Ojeda">Bob Ojeda</a>, <a href="Johnny%20Estrada">Johnny Estrada</a>, <a href="Jim%20Wohlford">Jim Wohlford</a> and <a href="Steve%20Stroughter">Steve Stroughter</a> all attended that college at one point or another as well).
In the 6th round of the <a href="2001%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20Draft">2001 Major League Baseball Draft</a>, Labandeira was drafted by the <a href="Montreal%20Expos">Montreal Expos</a> after posting superlative numbers in college. In , he <a href="Batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">hit</a> .367 while belting 15 <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s and was a <a href="Western%20Athletic%20Conference">Western Athletic Conference</a> All-Star and the Western Athletic Conference Player of the Year.
On September 17, , Labandeira made his major league debut at the age of 25. In seven games that year, he had a .000 batting average in 14 at-bats. He wore the number 1 during his tenure in the major leagues. He currently ranks 10th on the All-Time list of most career at-bats without a <a href="Hit%20%28baseball%29">hit</a> by a non-pitcher. The record of 23 is shared by <a href="Larry%20Littleton">Larry Littleton</a> and <a href="Mike%20Potter%20%28baseball%29">Mike Potter</a>.
He spent all of and playing for Harrisburg and Washington's Triple-A affiliate, the <a href="New%20Orleans%20Zephyrs">New Orleans Zephyrs</a>. In July 2005, Labandeira was suspended 15 games for violating the policies in the Minor League Drug Prevention and Treatment Program. In , Labandeira played for the <a href="Florida%20Marlins">Florida Marlins</a> Triple-A affiliate, the <a href="Albuquerque%20Isotopes">Albuquerque Isotopes</a>. He became a free agent at the end of the season. On April 22, , he signed a minor league contract with the <a href="Tampa%20Bay%20Rays">Tampa Bay Rays</a>. He was released on July 26, 2008. On July 31, he signed with the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Royals">Kansas City Royals</a> and became a free agent at the end of the season.
He is now an assistant coach on the Reedley College Baseball Team and an <a href="scout%20%28sport%29">area scout</a> for the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> based in <a href="Northern%20California">Northern California</a>.
Personal life.
Labandeira was married in January 2007 to college sweetheart, Rebecca Witt and they currently reside in <a href="Fresno%2C%20California">Fresno, California</a>.
